He moved on.  
“I say, sir!” the girl called after him.  
“What’s up?”  
She hesitated.  
“I’d love to hang out with you for an hour, kind gentleman, but I’m feeling shy right now. Can you spare me six copecks for a drink? Please?”  
Raskolnikov handed her the first coins he found—fifteen copecks.  
“Wow, what a nice guy!”  
“What’s your name?”  
“Call me Duclida.”  
“That’s a bit much,” one of the other women chimed in, shaking her head at Duclida. “I can’t believe you’d ask like that. I’d be too embarrassed…”  
Raskolnikov glanced at her. She was a thirty-year-old with pockmarks, bruises, and a swollen lip. She spoke softly but seriously. “Where have I read about someone facing death who thinks that even standing alone on a tiny rock in the middle of a stormy ocean is better than dying? Just to live, no matter how tough! … It’s so true! Good God, how true! Humans can be terrible! … And it’s just as bad to call them terrible,” he thought a moment later.  
He turned down another street. “Ugh, the Palais de Cristal!”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on the value of life amidst his interactions with a girl and a critical woman, contemplating the nature of existence and human vileness.
